snippet.textDisplay:
As a recent grad with a BSc in Geology I love that this channel has taken on this issue. I have some questions that I am hoping someone can help me out with.


1) Has time dilation due to universal expansion been taken into consideration when calculating the age of the earth? When calculating decay constants? (Also is there a reason why this question may be invalid?)
2) A previous SpaceTime video mentioned that the fundamental constants may be changing. If over large timescales even this pillar of our understanding of Physics is subject to uncertainty how can we use the model of uniformitarianism to explain the age of the earth? ie: We have only been observing the way things work for a few centuries. We only understand things from our tiny sliver of geologic time which is not at all representative of the whole (imagine we were observing conditions right after the Chicxulub impact, or some other period with significantly different conditions than those found today).



I think a lot of the controversy over this topic comes down to the logical fallacy of an argument from Authority. Essentially the argument usually boils down to "Scientists say..." or "God says..." without actually going into the details of why each side believes what they do. The solution is to address the legitimate problems that surround each argument, instead descending into a futile argument about what is the greater authority, God or Science. For example: https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0026-1394/52/3/S51 this article outlines the issues with radiometric dating. Radiometric dating is often presented as a foolproof solution in order to persuade people that the earth is old. Realizing that it is not a fool proof solution, but it is the best we've got right now actually has more impact than pushing it as a foolproof solution.
snippet.textOriginal:

1) Has time dilation due to universal expansion been taken into consideration when calculating the age of the earth? When calculating decay constants? (Also is there a reason why this question may be invalid?)

If over large timescales even this pillar of our understanding of Physics is subject to uncertainty how can we use the model of uniformitarianism to explain the age of the earth? ie: We have only been observing the way things work for a few centuries. We only understand things from our tiny sliver of geologic time which is not at all representative of the whole (imagine we were observing conditions right after the Chicxulub impact, or some other period with significantly different conditions than those found today). 



I think a lot of the controversy over this topic comes down to the logical fallacy of an argument from Authority. Essentially the argument usually boils down to "Scientists say..." or "God says..." without actually going into the details of why each side believes what they do. The solution is to address the legitimate problems that surround each argument, instead descending into a futile argument about what is the greater authority, God or Science. For example: https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0026-1394/52/3/S51 this article outlines the issues with radiometric dating. snippet.textDisplay: Has the earth really gone around the sun 4.5 billion times?  Surely the length of a sidereal year has drifted over the life of our planet.  Simulations of how the planets got to their current orbits show more volatility than might be commonly guessed.

snippet.textDisplay: Surly the Copernican Principle assumes the fact that we aren't the only intelligent life form that exists in the entire universe. Something we have absolutely no proof of, yet. The mathematics etc suggests that this is highly unlikely but as of now we are the only known observers of the universe. I know it's supposed to say more about the fact that physics is the same everywhere and that we can take it for granted that, if other observers do exist then their physics will be the same as ours. Still as of now we can in some ways assume we're in a privileged position as the only observer's of the universe.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi, first of all would like to appreciate your efforts for making such complex scientific researches, theories, principles and laws explained in a simple way for understanding.
Secondly would like to ask, as we are aware of space, time & gravity. Since we assume/know that a dot/point with intense High/infinite energy blew up and spread in space as different forms of energy But what is Space itself? How is it formed? Where does this space came from? What is nature/ingredients of space?

snippet.textDisplay: RCD relies on the assumption that nuclear decay rates are constant.  This assumption was empirically disproven by Brookhaven National Lab in 1986 by Alburger et al and later confirmed by M.A. Silver et al in 2010 which leads to the conclusion that the only way that RCD can be reliable is if the conditions controlling decay rates stays constant which is disproven by the experiments referenced.
snippet.textOriginal: RCD relies on the assumption that nuclear decay rates are constant.  This assumption was empirically disproven by Brookhaven National Lab in 1986 by Alburger et al and later confirmed by M.A. Silver et al in 2010 which leads to the conclusion that the only way that RCD can be reliable is if the conditions controlling decay rates stays constant which is disproven by the experiments referenced.

snippet.textDisplay: There is no expansion; only continuous movement of plasma-tic energy. Electricity is what makes matter coalesce, but it is a balancing act. We have no proof of a beginning; only this idea that we were created. How short sighted of our species to make such claims. Better it not to talk about a theory as though it is a theory, rather than fact?
